The first grants for high speed projects and upgrades to existing service could be awarded this summer. content: quote: High-speed rail would be nice. Anyone who's been to Europe will agree. Anyone who's been to Europe also knows the DISTANCES covered by this rail system is far less than the distances required to cross the US. Berlin to Rome is approx 700 miles..the same distance from Knoxville TN to Miami FL. Assuming a train moving at 200 MPH did not have tyo make any stops (not economically likely), it would take 3.5 hours to make such a trip...opposed to 1.5 hours on an airplane. The longer the trip the greater loss of time with a 3000 mile train trip taking 15 hrs vs. a 6 hour plane ride to cover the same distance.

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

content: quote: High-speed rail would be nice. Anyone who's been to Europe will agree. Anyone who's been to Europe also knows the DISTANCES covered by this rail system is far less than the distances required to cross the US. Berlin to Rome is approx 700 miles..the same distance from Knoxville TN to Miami FL. Assuming a train moving at 200 MPH did not have tyo make any stops (not economically likely), it would take 3.5 hours to make such a trip...opposed to 1.5 hours on an airplane. The longer the trip the greater loss of time with a 3000 mile train trip taking 15 hrs vs. a 6 hour plane ride to cover the same distance.

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

Air travel was always intended to be high speed travel, for those that could afford it and not "mass" transit... As air travel improved, better aircraft, pressurized cabins, so that you could fly above the weather and over the mountains, instead of "down in it" and "through the mountains", more and more people began to use air travel over train travel... Then in the late 1970s, the Kennedy's, er I mean the democratic party, thought that anyone who could afford the price of a bus ticket, should be able to fly and deregulated the airline industry and it has degenerated to what it is today... Has anyone noticed the vast distances that a high speed rail system would have to transit in the U.S., as opposed to Japan, France and the other E.U. nations?... Talk about an opportunity for some of this nations enemies to sabotage rails and bridges, especially in the "open and isolated" areas in the mountains and across the deserts?... Can you also say "flash floods" and "rock slides", kinda of tough thing to hit at 65 and 70 MPH, let alone at say around 300 MPH... Just wondering... Respectfully, SUNLINER81

content: quote: High-speed rail would be nice. Anyone who's been to Europe will agree. Anyone who's been to Europe also knows the DISTANCES covered by this rail system is far less than the distances required to cross the US. Berlin to Rome is approx 700 miles..the same distance from Knoxville TN to Miami FL. Assuming a train moving at 200 MPH did not have tyo make any stops (not economically likely), it would take 3.5 hours to make such a trip...opposed to 1.5 hours on an airplane. The longer the trip the greater loss of time with a 3000 mile train trip taking 15 hrs vs. a 6 hour plane ride to cover the same distance.

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

content: quote: High-speed rail would be nice. Anyone who's been to Europe will agree. Anyone who's been to Europe also knows the DISTANCES covered by this rail system is far less than the distances required to cross the US. Berlin to Rome is approx 700 miles..the same distance from Knoxville TN to Miami FL. Assuming a train moving at 200 MPH did not have tyo make any stops (not economically likely), it would take 3.5 hours to make such a trip...opposed to 1.5 hours on an airplane. The longer the trip the greater loss of time with a 3000 mile train trip taking 15 hrs vs. a 6 hour plane ride to cover the same distance.

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

content: quote: High-speed rail would be nice. Anyone who's been to Europe will agree. Anyone who's been to Europe also knows the DISTANCES covered by this rail system is far less than the distances required to cross the US. Berlin to Rome is approx 700 miles..the same distance from Knoxville TN to Miami FL. Assuming a train moving at 200 MPH did not have tyo make any stops (not economically likely), it would take 3.5 hours to make such a trip...opposed to 1.5 hours on an airplane. The longer the trip the greater loss of time with a 3000 mile train trip taking 15 hrs vs. a 6 hour plane ride to cover the same distance.

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

content: quote: High-speed rail would be nice. Anyone who's been to Europe will agree. Anyone who's been to Europe also knows the DISTANCES covered by this rail system is far less than the distances required to cross the US. Berlin to Rome is approx 700 miles..the same distance from Knoxville TN to Miami FL. Assuming a train moving at 200 MPH did not have tyo make any stops (not economically likely), it would take 3.5 hours to make such a trip...opposed to 1.5 hours on an airplane. The longer the trip the greater loss of time with a 3000 mile train trip taking 15 hrs vs. a 6 hour plane ride to cover the same distance.

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

The longer the trip the greater loss of time with a 3000 mile train trip taking 15 hrs vs. a 6 hour plane ride to cover the same distance.

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

The first grants for high speed projects and upgrades to existing service could be awarded this summer. content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

"My high-speed rail proposal will lead to innovations that change the way we travel in America," Obama said in announcing the first steps of an initiative that will tap $8 billion in economic stimulus money through 2012. The first grants for high speed projects and upgrades to existing service could be awarded this summer. content: Not to mention, every mile of track would require upgrade to support the increase in speed. This is a monumental expenditure for a non-consumer driven service. The market for passenger rail traffic in Europe is over a century old. In America? It hasn't been viable since the 1940s. Cargo, yes. Passengers, no. People want to either drive or fly and the supporting infrastructure of food service, rental car and ground transportation is geared to those industries. Ever been to the AMTRAK station in a city like Birmingham AL? Charlotte NC? There are NO facilites for food service or rental cars for miles, and the stations consist of a single ticket window and a waiting room smaller than my dentist's. Also, Charlotte's trains stop between 1 and 2 AM. That's it. No other times are available. If you miss your train, you can either drive 30 minutes to beat it to the next station by five minutes, or wait another day. Don't get me wrong, I love to travel by rail. It's more comfortable, relaxed and I don't feel like a sardine in the seat. But it isn't viable stateside. There just isn't demand necessary to increase the service between cities, no matter how economical it might seem. Throwing millions of $$s at it isn't going to bring the customers and services to the stations anytime soon. Sullivan013

content: quote: Originally posted by Motive25: quote: Originally posted by GunnyRet03: quote: Originally posted by Motive25: quote: Originally posted by beatleh60: quote: High-speed rail would be nice. Anyone who's been to Europe will agree. Anyone who's been to Europe also knows the DISTANCES covered by this rail system is far less than the distances required to cross the US. Berlin to Rome is approx 700 miles..the same distance from Knoxville TN to Miami FL. Assuming a train moving at 200 MPH did not have tyo make any stops (not economically likely), it would take 3.5 hours to make such a trip...opposed to 1.5 hours on an airplane. The longer the trip the greater loss of time with a 3000 mile train trip taking 15 hrs vs. a 6 hour plane ride to cover the same distance. You also have to factor in the time it takes to park your car at the airport, take the shuttle to the terminal and get through security. Then there are all those pesky weather and ATC delays. content: quote: Originally posted by soscorpio: quote: High-speed rail would be nice. Anyone who's been to Europe will agree. Us not having it, is testimony to the unconstitutional influence big oil and banks have over our city, state, and federal gov'ts. many always say "Pfffft" "that would take a big conspiracy", no, it would not. Create positions of wealth and power and those that fill those positions will do whatever it takes to maintain them. The reason that "rail travel" went out was and is, that freight was the "bread and butter" of the rail industry, passenger service was a "side business"... Before "air travel", "rail travel" was all that you had... Air travel was never intended to be "mass" transit, as it is today... Air travel was always intended to be high speed travel, for those that could afford it and not "mass" transit... As air travel improved, better aircraft, pressurized cabins, so that you could fly above the weather and over the mountains, instead of "down in it" and "through the mountains", more and more people began to use air travel over train travel... Then in the late 1970s, the Kennedy's, er I mean the democratic party, thought that anyone who could afford the price of a bus ticket, should be able to fly and deregulated the airline industry and it has degenerated to what it is today... Has anyone noticed the vast distances that a high speed rail system would have to transit in the U.S., as opposed to Japan, France and the other E.U. nations?... Talk about an opportunity for some of this nations enemies to sabotage rails and bridges, especially in the "open and isolated" areas in the mountains and across the deserts?... Can you also say "flash floods" and "rock slides", kinda of tough thing to hit at 65 and 70 MPH, let alone at say around 300 MPH... Just wondering... Respectfully, SUNLINER81
